componenttext:
Welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. My name is Sylvia, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions]  Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I will now turn the call over to over to Alicia Charity, Alicia, you may begin.

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Ameriprise Financial's Third Quarter Earnings Call. On the call with me today are Jim Cracchiolo, Chairman and CEO; and Walter Berman, our Chief Financial Officer. Following their remarks, we'll be happy to take you
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Ameriprise Financial's Third Quarter Earnings Call. On the call with me today are Jim Cracchiolo, Chairman and CEO; and Walter Berman, our Chief Financial Officer. Following their remarks, we'll be happy to take your questions. 
Turning to Slide 2 of the earnings presentation materials that are available on our website, includes a discussion of forward-looking statements. Specifically, that during the call, you will hear reference to various non-GAAP financial measures, which we believe provide insight into the company's operations. Reconciliation of non-GAAP numbers to their respective GAAP numbers can be found in today's materials. Some statements that we make on this call may be forward-looking, reflecting management's expectations about future events and operating plans and performance. These forward-looking statements speak only as of today's date and involve a number of risks and uncertainties. A sample list of factors and risks that could cause actual results to be materially different from forward-looking statements can be found in today's earnings release, our 2015 annual report to shareholders, our 2015 10-K report and the first and second quarter of 2016 10-Q reports. We take no obligation to update publicly or revise these forward-looking statements.
Turning to Slide 3, you see our GAAP financial results for the third quarter. Below that, you see our operating results, which management believes enhance the understanding of our business by reflecting the underlying performance of our core operations and facilitate a more meaningful trend analysis. Additionally, we completed our annual noncash unlocking and long-term security in the third quarter. We included operating results, excluding unlocking, for additional transparency. The comments of management makes on the call today will focus on operating financial results as well as results excluding unlocking. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Jim.

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and thank you for joining our third quarter earnings call. I'll provide my perspective on the business and the progress we're making, and Walt will discuss our financials, including the noncash impact of annual unlocking. Regarding Ameriprise ove
componenttext:
Hello, and thank you for joining our third quarter earnings call. I'll provide my perspective on the business and the progress we're making, and Walt will discuss our financials, including the noncash impact of annual unlocking. 
Regarding Ameriprise overall, like others, we're experiencing headwinds in the operating environment from industry trends, the regulatory change agenda globally as well as geopolitical volatility. During the time of change for the industry, I feel good about how Ameriprise is positioned in our focus on serving our clients and advisers. The current environment amplifies the value of the advising solutions that Ameriprise provides. Today, I'll cover our underlying operating results, excluding unlocking. Total assets under management, administration increased nicely to $796 billion, and that includes the typical foreign exchange translation and asset management. Financially, earnings were down a bit, while earnings per diluted share, excluding unlocking, increased 4%. As always, we're closely managing our expenses while continuing to invest for growth. Return on equity, excluding unlocking and AOCI, was a healthy 23.8%. Our business generates good free cash flow. And as you know, maintaining our excellent financial foundation is core to how we operate the company. These consistent management principles enable Ameriprise to navigate this time of change and invest in the business as well as return capital to shareholders at a meaningful level. For the third quarter, we returned more than $500 million to shareholders through our share repurchases and dividends, bringing our total return for 2016 so far to more than $1.6 billion. 
Let's move to the businesses. In Advice & Wealth Management, we're situated well with our strong advice positioning and value proposition. I spent a lot of time during the year with our advisers and just returned from our private wealth advisers conference with over our 900 of our top producers are gathered. They're feeling good about their ability to run strong practices and the growth opportunity at Ameriprise as well as the way we support them during times of change. We believe more than ever our advice value proposition is strong and desirable. Personnel comprehensive advice is critical in handling the volatility and issues facing consumers as they look to achieve their long-term goals. For the quarter, retail client assets grew nicely, up 10%, and we had nearly $3 billion in net inflows in fee-based investment event advisory accounts in the quarter. Our investment advisory platform is in the top 5 of mutual fund adviser and consistent growth driver for Ameriprise. In addition, we delivered operating earnings of $231 million, up 5% from a year ago; and our margin increased to 18.2% for the quarter. 
As we continue to serve more clients in fee-based relationships, transactional business represents less of our total production. As an example, more than 70% of our gross deal concession is asset-based. Average advice productivity is holding strong at over $500,000 on a trailing 12-month basis. As we look to grow the business, we're ensuring advisers fully benefit from the investments we've made, including our technology platforms, our e-tools and online. Our advisers are more efficient when they use capabilities like our e-file delivery and e-signature tools and more productive when they use our aggregation tool like Total View. We're meeting more and more clients online, and visits to ameriprise.com are up significantly year-over-year. And engagement with clients and prospects on social media is a continued strength of ours. Brand awareness is another component for growth. We're back on the air with our Be Brilliant advertising. And the next chapter of our Be Brilliant ads will be live in January as we continue to reinforce the confidence clients can realize from working with Ameriprise adviser. In addition to focusing on client growth, recruiting is going well. We added another 80 experienced, productive advisers, bring us to about 250 advisers year-to-date. And our pipeline is looking good into the next quarter and next year as Ameriprise stands out as a destination for successful advisers who appreciate our advice value proposition and supportive culture.
Now let's turn to the Department of Labor's fiduciary rule. Clearly, it's a significant change for the industry and a top priority for us. I believe Ameriprise is well positioned to handle the changes required to respond to the rule and to help advisers do the same. Frankly, this is a complex change, and it will continue to consume a lot of our energy. We're dedicating significant resources and leadership them to manage it in a regimented way. 
Consistent with our financial planning leadership, Ameriprise is one of the largest providers of fee-based investment advice, and we already operate as a fiduciary after a very high standard of care. In terms of our product offering, we're focused on minimizing disruption to our clients and ensuring our advisers continue to have a broad suite of solutions to help meet client needs, grow and protect the assets and achieve their goals. We continue to believe providing the best of choice is important, and therefore, we've been hard at work to enable both advisory and brokerage options for clients and advisers. Ameriprise has a very strong client's foundation and conducts robust due diligence of the product and platforms we offer. We've always been although able to operate in a heavily regulated environment and comply with the requirements while also delivering an excellent client experience as we focus on helping our clients achieving their financial goals over a lifetime. Because of our robust position and compliant processes and training already in place, we're operating from a position of strength relative to many others in the industry. As a company, we think all of these elements very seriously and worked to integrate compliance and supervision throughout our business processes across the firm. Here's how we're approaching the rule and the support we're providing our advisers to adopt to the new landscape. Let's start with our investment advisory business. 
We're making the choice to use long-standing exemptions under for our investment advisory business, and we believe this is the most appropriate way to continue to offer clients more flexibility and investment choices while offering our advice the most protection and flexibility. The adjustments necessary to comply with this rule will be fully executed by the end of the first quarter of next year to be ready for the April deadline, and we're working with advisers now to help them execute the changes. 
With that, I'll turn to brokerage and our commission business. We intend to use the exception for brokerage and other commission-based recommendations. The deal will introduce the BIC and large part to address your challenges for brokerage and other commission-based accounts under the framework. The big exception amid compensation that varies by product as long as the requirements of the exemption are met. This is an area where we are starting to see some changes across the industry relating to product availability and product compensation as it would apply to products like mutual funds and annuities. Ameriprise, like others in the industry, will likely need to their offering help advisers meet the rules and duties of prudence and loyalty. Similar to the approach we're taking in an advisory, we want to continue to offer flexibility  and choice. In addition, we have best-in-class due diligence and strong supervision, which will further enhance, where necessary, with both qualitative, quantitative filters to ensure the country to have robust solutions that will be appropriate in the qualified market. As you know, there will also be new requirements for IRA [indiscernible]. Today, we have industry-leading [indiscernible] or approach that help clients evaluate their options for the retirement plan assets and working right now to determine how we will enhance that as appropriate. We will also build on our already strong and comprehensive rollover education disclosure materials and documentation to meet the given expectations. As you would expect, it's very important to us to bring this to life for advisers to support them to comply with the new rule. Last April, we began executing our comprehensive communications and training plan, including holding a series of webcasts that continue to throughout the remainder of the year. Throughout the first quarter, we'll be conducting extensive local in-person training to help our advisers and the teams prepare to comply for the initial effect of the date of April 10. Clearly, this is a large change agenda for the industry. We have devoted tremendous resources and are making progress and have a lot of work to do, and you'll see that across the industry whether or how they decide to do business. We continue to review the regulation in all of its intricacies to ensure we can meet all the requirements of the new fiduciary standards to minimize potential exposure to the firm and our advisers for having due diligence, analysis and documentation as well as the appropriate supervision necessary. Given what we know, we feel comfortable that we can effectively navigate through it. Next quarter, I will share even more about our compliance approach and progress and our training and implementation. Again, we feel comfortable that we will continue to offer a broad suite of products with the necessary oversight. As I stated earlier, we already apply a rigorous review and due diligence on products we offer and have extensive disclosures in place. While there'll be additional disclosures and documentation for our adviser going forward, based on what we know at this time, we believe these requirements will be manageable. In this regulatory environment, the importance of delivering advice is even more significant than ever. We know clients and consumers are looking for us to serve them holistically. The growth opportunity we have is compelling. 
To summarize, we're delivering nice growth and profitability in Advice & Wealth Management. We're working closely and comprehensively with advisers to manage the overall change ahead. And we feel good about our near- and long-term opportunity to serve even more consumers with advice. 
Let's move to annuities and protection. I'll focus more on the underlying businesses, and Walt will cover the financials. In annuities, DA account balance is about 4% year-over-year. And while our DA sales are down year-over-year, we look to be better than the industry given our financial planning focus. We're helping our advisers meet their clients' retirement income needs to make it easier for clients and advisers to conduct business. As an example, we've seen good results from the adviser workshops we held, which focus on the new challenges for today's retirement. And we've seen good uptake on our enhanced digital tools that help advisers present retirement solutions. On the fix side, the story remains the same. The overall book is performing as expected in the slow interest rate environment, and we're not adding to it at this time.
In life insurance, the UL, UL account balances were up 5%, and overall sales were down like others in the industry. Overall, claims experience remain within an expected range. During the quarter, we launched an index account for our VUL product that provides the benefits of accumulating cash value with the added safety of an index core, and we're seeing a nice initial response by clients and advisers. 
Finally, in auto and home, we begin to see improvements in business results from the changes we've been making. Both current and our accident year loss trends are showing solid improvement. As I shared previously, we're taking a number of actions, including enhanced pricing sophistication and raising rates in both Auto and Home all the lines, with improved risk quality through tighter underwriting and more disciplined exposure management. We also enhanced our claims organization, and as a result, we're seeing better outcomes that will contribute to a higher-performing portfolio over time. 
With regard to the quarter, in leading with many industry players, we have higher-than-expected capital as we're making systemic changes to lessen the impact of cats on our results, including improving cats-related pricing and strengthening the team handling cats claims, including adding more field adjusters. Overall, we're making good progress. I feel more confident in the team we now have in place and the actions that we're taking to bring the business back to historical profitability. 
Let's turn to asset management. During this significant period change for the industry, we're managing headwinds and had a good level of scale, capabilities and distributions to navigate this period well. For the quarter, assets under management declined slightly to $468 billion. However, that included an unfavorable foreign exchange translation, which impacted assets under management by about $14 billion year-over-year. In terms of [indiscernible] we had a little over $4 billion out in the quarter compared to more than $7 billion at this time last year. Global retail outflows improved substantially to $1.9 billion in the quarter, excluding former parent company-related flows and inflows from acquisitions. In the U.S. retail, we're seeing some improvement. While we're in outflows, we've improved gross sales by nearly 10% over the past 12 months. We're also earning a higher market share on many of our key intermediary distribution platforms. This is at a time when overall industry sales in the active space are down and we're all facing slower activity on the equity side of the business. Overall, redemptions have slowed, and that includes in the Acorn fund, which was about $600 million out in the quarter. Performance versus peers has improved with the changes that we made, and we're focused on continuing to generate competitive performance to strengthen long-term numbers and helping the turnaround of this product line. 
In the U.K. and European retail, as you know, retail outflows spiked in June and July because of Brexit. As we moved through the quarter, the level of redemptions slowed to end the quarter largely neutral. Our teams have done an excellent job navigating this environment, including in the property space where we preserved value for investors and has moved the reopening of our fund. If market conditions remain stable for the remainder of the year, we expect better results in the fourth quarter. In terms of institutional, we and others industry have experienced a slowdown in the rate of funding, which contributed to about $2 billion in outflows in the quarter. That included a loss of one of the remaining Acorn mandates around $700 million in the quarter. We feel good about the rest of '16 and into '17 as our list of one not funded mandates is good, with wins in both domestic and international that should fund in the fourth quarter and into next year. Our win rate remains strong, and we have a healthy pipeline of opportunities in a number of equity credit and solution multi-asset strategies. Consistent with our normal level of outflows in the form of parent portfolios, we had about $1.4 billion of lower fee outflows with the majority from Zürich. Outflows in U.S. Trust IMA significantly slowed as we moved through the quarter. I would also note, we had about $1 billion of inflows from the EGA acquisition. 
Regarding performance, we're very focused on ensuring we have a strong performing credit lines to serve individual and institutional investor needs that includes delivering consistent performance expectations in existing products and developing new product and strategies as we look forward. With a 110 foreign five-star Morningstar-rated funds, Colombia Threadneedle as an excellent track record of generating competitive performance across asset classes and stocks. We have particular strong performance in a number of funds in domestic and international equities as well as across taxable and tax-exempt fixed income at Colombia and asset allocation products globally. 
In regard to U.K. and Europe, we've been able to remain focused on our business and feel we're in a good position to manage the change related to Brexit in what will be a multiyear transition. Colombia Threadneedle already has an established fund range and presence in Europe, and we're in a good position to continue to serve European investors going forward. We're focused on expanding the scope of our Luxembourg-based management company. We plan to further replicate a more complete product line and establish a broader asset management presence in the EU post-Brexit. Importantly, we have a well-resourced and experienced product development team with a capacity to ensure the needs of our clients are met in an efficient and transparent manner. Like the industry, we'll be looking for further clarification that will inform us and others on how to manage the transition of our clients. Again, this will take time, but I feel that we're in a good position.
As we look forward, we're doing a number of things on the product development side to capture flows. In addition to enhancements to our traditional mutual fund product line, we're further building out our managed account and solution businesses. We're seeing good interest in our multi-asset, tax-efficient and adaptive-risk products. In fact, our U.S. retail product has grown to north of $1 billion in assets under management. We've also completed the EGA acquisition that strengthened our strategic data and ETF capabilities and complements multi-products we developed and launched earlier this year. This is a long-term growth opportunity in the U.S. that we're beginning to build upon. 
Finally, we are a recognized leader in the U.K. for responsible investment, and we're working to expand that capability here in the United States. Our U.S. social bond fund is a unique product, and our recently launched strategic data products include a sustainability screen. Similar to strategic data work, it's an initiative that we intend to grow more fully over time. 
Our asset management business is and at scale business, and we're generating competitive margin in a challenging period. We're managing expenses well, knowing we have revenue pressure from the level of outflows we've experienced. We're seeing some nice underlying trends in domestic and international. We have more work to do, and I feel good about the teams in place and their execution focus. 
Now for Ameriprise overall, we have a strong base and a good track record for handling periods of industry change. Ameriprise has always been able to operate in a heavily regulated environment, strongly compliant, delivering excellent experience as we help clients achieve their financial goals. Our excellent capital position provides flexibility for both organic growth and inorganic opportunities in both wealth management and asset management. We also have a very solid annuities and protections business. We're bringing in a very strong focus so that we can navigate the current environment. As we look forward, I feel good about the long-term opportunity Ameriprise has in the marketplace as we focus on delivering for our clients. 
Now Walt will cover the financials, and I'll be back to take your questions.

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Ameriprise delivered another solid quarter of financial performance on an underlying basis. As you saw in our release, results were impacted negatively by our annual noncash unlocking and unusual items. Advice & Wealth Management continues
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Ameriprise delivered another solid quarter of financial performance on an underlying basis. As you saw in our release, results were impacted negatively by our annual noncash unlocking and unusual items. Advice & Wealth Management continues to be our primary growth segment, with improved inflows, strong experience adviser recruiting and excellent margin expansion. And as the management remains impacted by industry trends away from active management, but we're seeing good traction in few areas that Jim discussed and maintaining our focus on sustaining a good level of profitability.
Annuities and life and health insurance underlying profitability remains stable, but with slower growth in the short term given the environment and regulatory changes. This remains a strong source of capital generation. Our trends continue to emerge in Auto and Home, and we began to recognize them in their financial results this quarter, potentially with more to come as we evaluate loss performance. Our balance sheet is strong, and we returned over $500 million of capital to shareholders in the quarter.
Let's turn to consolidated results beginning on Slide 6. Revenue was up slightly from last year to $2.9 billion. Excluding the impact of unlocking in both years, Advice & Wealth Management represents more than 40% of overall revenues and continues to trend up given our good growth in client assets. This was offset by pressure from outflows and asset management and insurance and annuities interest rate pressure. Auto and Home has had a nice revenue growth from the rate actions taken, with rate increases in about 3/4 of the states we do business with during 2016.
Let's turn to Slide 7. Ameriprise continues to demonstrate our ability to navigate across business cycles and deliver a solid EPS growth and a strong return on equity. Operating performance in the quarter included a net negative $0.12 of items. First, we had $29 million pretax or $0.11 of total catastrophic losses in the quarter, of which $0.03 was above our expectations. Additionally, we had $0.11 on favorable long-term care model corrections and $0.06 of unusual corporate items related to low-income housing and DOL implementation, partially offset by a positive $0.08 from [indiscernible] and in Auto and Home reserve release. Excluding these items, underlying EPS was $2.41, up 4%. We're managing expenses while making the right investments to adjust the regulatory changes and support future growth. We would expect the overall expenses to ramp up as we approach of the DOL implementation date in April.
Our business continues to generate significant free cash flow, and disciplined capital management has driven EPS and return on equity growth. 
Let's turn to segment performance, starting on Slide 8. First, the advice & Wealth Management businesses continues to perform very well, delivering solid financial results and strong business metrics. Jim spoke about a strong leading indicators we see in this business. Excellent recruiting, stronger advisory retention and client acquisition are all contributing to record client asset levels. Operating net revenue was up 2% from last year to $1.3 billion in the quarter from solid rap net inflows, higher earnings on brokerage cash and asset base fees. We are continuing to see our business shift more towards advisory, which we would expect to continue and possibly even accelerate with DOL implementation. 
G&A expenses are continuing to be tightly managed, down 1% from last year. We typically see seasonally higher expenses in the fourth quarter where project spending and advertising tend to increase. We delivered a record operating margin in the quarter at 18.2%, up 60 basis points from last year and up 50 basis points sequentially. 
Let's turn to asset management on Slide 9. Operating net revenue was down 5% to $740 million, primarily from net outflows and foreign exchange translation. We are prudently managing expenses for overall expenses, down 3%; and G&A, down 2%. Pretax operating earnings was down 14% to $155 million, largely from outflows. As a reminder, the impact of foreign exchange translation is immaterial to earnings. The adjusted margin in the quarter was in our expected range at 36%.
Turning to Annuities on Slide 10. This segment is performing in line with our expectations. Variable annuity pretax operating earnings was $114 [ph] million, essentially flat to a year ago, excluding unlocking and remuneration in both periods. Variable annuities has unfavorable unlocking of $220 million this year due to higher consistency on living benefit contracts and continued low interest rates as you've seen across the industry. Our long-term interest rate assumption remained unchanged, but we extended the period it would take for rates to reach our long-term level to 5.5 years.
As a result of updating the assumption for products with living benefits on our SOP reserves, there will be an ongoing impact of variable annuities earnings going forward. Fixed annuity pretax operating earnings were essentially flat to last year at $24 million, excluding unlocking. Unlocking this year was largely due to good consistency as our clients are lapsing at a slower pace than we previously modeled. I'd also like to note that the underlying profitability in this business has sustained a bit better than we expected this year. This quarter benefited from some gains relating to prepayments of investments. We are continuing to see account decline given minimal sales in this rate environment. 
Turning to the Protection segment on Slide 11. Pretax operating earnings, excluding unlocking, was $31 million in the quarter. There were a number of moving parts in the quarter, some I'm going to address like [indiscernible] long-term care and Auto and Home separately. Let's first focus on life and health, excluding long-term care. Underlying pretax operating earnings were up from last year to $74 million, excluding unlocking, new version and a premium correction in the year-ago period. Unlocking was a favorable $70 [ph] million, primarily from increased value of future reinsurance recoverables due to slightly worse mortality, partially offset by continued low interest rates. Long-term care had a pretax operating loss of $73 million, which included a $37 million of unfavorable impact of our annual LTC review and a negative $29 million from a model correction. The third quarter annual LTC review was negatively impacted by lower interest rates, morbidity trends and elevated reinsurance expense. Underlying results were a loss of $7 million, essentially flat to last year and consistent with our expectations for this block.
Auto and Home had an $8 million operating loss in the quarter, including excess cat losses of $7 million. As we previously told you, the actions we've taken to improve our underwriting, pricing and claims practices are taking hold, and the positive trends have emerged. Therefore, in the third quarter, we lowered at the ratio for the 2016 accident year and released $10 million of prior year reserves. We anticipate being able to make additional adjustments if these positive trends continue.
I will conclude with a few comments on the balance sheet on Slide 12. As we have told you before, Ameriprise maintains a strong balance sheet that we will use opportunistically. We have over $2 billion of excess capital, and our estimate and RBC ratio remains above 500%. Our hedging programs continue to work well, and the investment portfolio is well positioned and diversified. We returned approximately 130% of operating earnings, excluding unlocking, to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. This is consistent with the level of shares we repurchased before with significant increase in the first half of the year but remains well above our baseline 90% to 100% of earnings. 
With that, we'll take your questions.

componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And my second question is around just the trends in the business. So nice to see organic growth pick back up this quarter. How do you guys view the sustainability of that fee rate in the world where kind of scrutiny on fees and the awareness around fees is clearly rising?

componenttext: Well, when you look at our fee rate, overall, I mean, the feel rate also includes a lot of some of our activities regarding the financial activities. And so some of those services that we performed for clients are also embedded in our fee rate, and we do that and look at it sometimes on a consolidated basis and advise us that's the way they price their book. And so in that, there are a lot of services around the full comprehensive financial plan and services rendered in that regard.

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I also wanted to touch on the potential deal impact on the Advisory business or around the Advice & Wealth Management business. So it seems like we're starting to see some bifurcation in approaches or strategic views from different advisory businesses, wh
componenttext: I also wanted to touch on the potential deal impact on the Advisory business or around the Advice & Wealth Management business. So it seems like we're starting to see some bifurcation in approaches or strategic views from different advisory businesses, whether to continue to offer sensible options for clients and preserve, I guess, the flexibility  while tweaking product offerings, which seems to be what Ameriprise is doing. And then, those who are maybe taking more drastic measures of exiting the commission business where they be the brokerage business altogether. I just want to get a sense, as you're looking at the business and the future with euro, what gives you comfort that you can continue offering this flexibility today?

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we look -- we look to serve the client comprehensively and that's our planning approach. So we look to make sure that the client is getting the right solutions necessary for them to have a complete financial picture. In that regard, we feel that
componenttext: Well, as we look -- we look to serve the client comprehensively and that's our planning approach. So we look to make sure that the client is getting the right solutions necessary for them to have a complete financial picture. In that regard, we feel that even in the qualified part of the business, other products and services are necessary for them to be appropriate. As an example, we do believe in investment advisory. A lot part of our business is done that way, but investment advisory might not be for all clients based on a combination of the fees for it, based on the size of the account, et cetera, and that there may be more efficient and appropriate products for them, such as the fund in a particular circumstance, so our annuity for retirement income and guarantees. So what we're trying to do is give our advisers as much flexibility as possible with these products. We continue to be appropriate, both in the qualified as well as similar to a non-qualified in that regard. It doesn't mean that more business won't shift to investment advisory as it is today, but we want to give them the flexibility to do that. Now that does require more work on our part. It does require more compliance. In this require more due diligence. It does require more disclosures and documentation for adviser to do that fully funded the BIC. But we have the ability and the capabilities to support that, and that's what we want to try to do for our advisers as we move forward.

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up would be on excess the capital position and with the dislocation that may come with the implementation of DOL. Can you maybe talk about where you see opportunities to possibly deploy or maybe hope for M&A opportunities? And may
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up would be on excess the capital position and with the dislocation that may come with the implementation of DOL. Can you maybe talk about where you see opportunities to possibly deploy or maybe hope for M&A opportunities? And maybe also talk about what is best interest to you even with the dislocations that you may generate in the industry.

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we see opportunities that will continue as other players, either say, “hey, I can't support this business, and therefore, I'm not going to support activities like I'm not going to support BIC activities, et cetera, for commission-based product or tha
componenttext: So we see opportunities that will continue as other players, either say, “hey, I can't support this business, and therefore, I'm not going to support activities like I'm not going to support BIC activities, et cetera, for commission-based product or that we can't do the amount of extensive due diligence, disclosure, documentation appropriate to support advisers where I think more people may want to come to Ameriprise.” Now we're looking for people to come to Ameriprise that will fit our culture, that advice value proposition that really would continue to build in a way that they do business, our brand equity in the marketplace. So culturally, having the right fit appropriate to the quality business, that is what we're looking for. So what whether they be individual firms or advisers that want to join us, we'll be looking for that over time and I think there will be opportunities. Because as we're showing to you, we have a firm that has a lot of capability, but we're devoting tremendous resources. We have anywhere from 500 to 1,000 people working on this and DOL initiative right now embedded in our from, just based on how we're redeploying resources because the time frame to get this done is pretty short and the amount of effort to get it done is pretty significant. So we feel we do have the ability to do that. Many firms will not have that ability or be able to support their advisers to make that change. Remember, advisers have to make these changes across their book. And many advisers of 300 or 500 clients, and so it's a big change for them. And so we have the wherewithal and the capabilities to support our advisers through that. So if you look at M&A, it will be along those types of guidelines that we would continue to pursue, firms and people. We also see opportunities in the asset management space. Very clearly, this is a consolidated environment. As you can see, flows are difficult across the business. And you really do need a larger platforms and capabilities to sustain that type of business, put the proper market commensurate at its meeting the criteria that firms like ours are going to have moving forward. And we feel that Colombia Threadneedle has a lot of those capabilities, and so we'll continue to look to complement what we had put in place.

That was the primary element. We're seeing the trend, and this trend with the additional analysis, so we -- that's what drove the persistency on it. Obviously, we had other behavioral changes, but pretty much net [indiscernible] The change on the interest side as we evaluated this and basically extended the conversion time from 3.5 years to a 5.5 years and kept our long-term trends assumption the same.

componenttext: Okay. And then Jim, just one bigger-picture, strategic question. Do you think that being manufacturing distributer products provides the same competitive and economic just like it did historically? And the DOL, well, how do you think about maximizing the value of both your product and distribution capabilities?

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I would say, I do feel the Ameriprise today is a stronger firm because we have a combination of very strong distribution as well as manufacturing capabilities. Our manufacturing capabilities and the intellectual know-how and capability we have act
componenttext: Yes. So I would say, I do feel the Ameriprise today is a stronger firm because we have a combination of very strong distribution as well as manufacturing capabilities. Our manufacturing capabilities and the intellectual know-how and capability we have actually helps us in many regards to think about how our advisers can work better with products and services that are appropriate for them at the capabilities even to manage some of those various asset that we've deployed. Now with that, remember, in our channel, we only sell products consistent with what we offer from an industry perspective. They're very competitive. They operate in the same format, same pricing, same commission structure. Everything in that regard is no different. Having said that, we also, through our manufacturing, have the ability, like through Colombia and Threadneedle, because we can serve as at the number of people that we can serve more people globally retail institutions and leverage that capability. So I feel like Ameriprise has a number of strong [indiscernible] sort of a foundation and those complement each other over time. I think as we've proven to you that if you look at our both ability to generate earnings growth, the volatility of our earnings are lower. Our return has been higher from a combination of the businesses that we're in. Now we make sure each business is very much focused about it's to deliver and the core value of it. But I feel still, even the changes in the DOL, if you can provide good product, appropriate product consistent with what needs to be delivered to the consumer endpoint in an appropriate and beneficial way, then there's no reason why you can't be in those businesses. And remember, very few business today are just pure distributors. Now you can say, well, in the wealth management, independent space, but they're very tight margins. And in that regard, the sustainability of those businesses over time one can question.

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So very clearly, under [indiscernible] you have the ability to offer and operate with full discretion with no conflicts, et cetera, et cetera. That is part of the way we do our advisory business. There's also an exception called the PPA exemption tha
componenttext: Yes. So very clearly, under [indiscernible] you have the ability to offer and operate with full discretion with no conflicts, et cetera, et cetera. That is part of the way we do our advisory business. There's also an exception called the PPA exemption that allows nondiscretionary advisory accounts with compensation paid to the fiduciary advisers based on assets and its level across. And so those are the 2 exemptions that we will or the way operate on the result that we think is appropriate and has various professions appropriate as longs you satisfy those requirement, and that will be different than operating under the BIC standard which has its own exemption. So it would operate a little bit differently. It takes out of the ADF of private right of action as well as you would have under the BIC.

And that's the way we look at our close reinvestment for reimbursement, and that cost reimbursement will be consistent appropriate, and that's different than what the adviser. The adviser will not get various compensation based on product what type of platform there on the advisory base and that will all be consistent with what they get and why they're charged for the administration of those assets.

componenttext: Okay. And just the [indiscernible] first, the advisers, looks like, again, you're recruiting some productive advisers. You're losing some. It looks that the ones you're losing may be less productive. I mean, are you guys -- in terms of -- what are you are you shooting for try to break even on a net advisory count? Is that a realistic assumption? Or is the -- I guess the process where you always stand to lose a little bit more in less productive advisers than you'll gain in a more productive new advisers? And just as a quick follow-up to that, has the -- with the more stress in the independent brokerage industry, have you had to a be paying less to recruit productive advisers given the fact they may have less options now?

headline: Ameriprise Financial, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we don't look at it as sort of -- based on the number of account, we look at it as bringing in quality advisers and their books that would be appropriate for us, and we are recruiting more people that have higher productivity. And we've been bringing o
componenttext: So we don't look at it as sort of -- based on the number of account, we look at it as bringing in quality advisers and their books that would be appropriate for us, and we are recruiting more people that have higher productivity. And we've been bringing on, more recently, even many more million-dollars-plus producers and teams. So they are finding Ameriprise as a good home for them and appropriate from a cultural and on a support perspective. The people we are losing in those attrition numbers are some lower producers that are not hitting some other standards that we have. It also includes people who are retiring and moving their books to other advisers. So the assets that need, but if they are sort of moving out and transitioning their practices as they have set the successful transition and succession plans that we have our advisers do here. And we are seeing somewhat advisers come back even from the independent space that want more of the support and the value that we can provide to help them build and grow their practices rather than being just more continuing independent that don't get that level of that support out there. I would -- I think we would see a continuation of that pickup over time as more people are evaluating their businesses and their practices. I think even as you move into the RAA space, it's going to be more difficult. All of RAAs, including have to operate under a big standard. There's going to be a lot more compliance and supervision out there. The SEC is a stacking up to do that. They also make arrangements with FINRA to handle some of the activities that they did so that they can really focus on more of the advisory space now that it has grown. So I do believe that people are going to be need support. I think the compliance is going to be very important out there across the industry and the liability the people will have will continue to rise.

componenttext: So in regard to the M&A, as we have said to you consistently, so first let me start by saying that we will continue to look for strategic opportunities, that we have been a very disciplined buyer, and we will continue to be disciplined buyer out there, that M&A activities will fit where we think we could either grow the business, scale the business appropriately, get shareholder good return from the business, so we continue to help build that in certain platforms and capabilities that we want to continue to grow. I do believe there will be more opportunities coming. Again, it doesn't mean that we'll just jump of those opportunities. But if the right ones to come pst, we will look at them and evaluate them appropriately. We still have the wherewithal, a combination of the cash, more debt than we can actually go out to the market, if necessary, et cetera, to do appropriate acquisitions of reasonable size, even small or medium-size or even a bit larger if we really thought that was appropriate. But at the end of the day, we're still going to be a very disciplined buyer. We're going to be a very a permit to what our core businesses are and what will give us the strategic value longer term.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So in regard to the 12B-1s, most of that is a pass-through, particularly in the independent space that we have. The employees are not a pass-through. But in that regard, yes, there will be a piece that the firm has, a piece that adviser has, but all
componenttext: Yes. So in regard to the 12B-1s, most of that is a pass-through, particularly in the independent space that we have. The employees are not a pass-through. But in that regard, yes, there will be a piece that the firm has, a piece that adviser has, but all of that will go away starting January. To the extent that there aren't necessarily 12b-1  [indiscernible] that have not 12b-1 will be rebating anything different, but we will move to more of an institutional share class across our house. Now with that, it will affect some other fees that adviser has had in that regard, and they're evaluating their practices. They're evaluating the value and the services that they're rendering on that as well. And in the firm perspective, we are making adjustments for some of the things that we need to do to offset that as from a cost perspective or from a service perspective as well. Now we feel very appropriate that this is a move across the industry or will be across the industry. I think a number of players have moved that in some of their books, but we'll more fully moved to that, over time. And so we think it is reasonable and appropriate to do that consistently many of the funds that we offer didn't have the share classes of the despite. And so in those cases, we're waiting for some of them to get those share classes, but our date of execution and the platforms we put in place to handle that will be fully operational by the end of the year. So that we are allowed to be able to do that, but that's really where we moved, and we will move by the end of January.

But I could say this, by implementing and executing against to the BIC, it does require the firm to put more resources to ensure there is a greater level of what I would call both support compliance changes to product and platforms and capabilities there and then support the advisers and the training, et cetera. So an easier way for us to do with as well would have been, “hey, were not going to support that and get a big it will be a lot more efficient for the firm. It wouldn't be actually helping the advisory to achieve what they think they need to achieve from a quite and the impact from what would also be more significant. So I can't talk to them and their buck and the size of their activities and now important this is to them. But we do feel that we want to have our advisers as best as we can. We will continue to help our advisers as they want to do more advisory business. Remember, 70% of our fee our total GDC already is an fee-based businesses through our financial plan activities and the REP business, et cetera. So it's not as though Ameriprise is a leader in the advisory business. Having said that, even though this is a small part of the business, so you think the 30%, and you take only the piece for qualified, which is less about 1/2 of that or less, we still feel that we want to provide support necessary for our advisers so that they don't disrupt there quite activities or have the clients pay more for services already that for accounts upon us that they already offer. So that's what we're doing. I can't speak to other competitors in that regard. And again, we think that we can be in compliance. If we can't, we want do it. But we feel we can be in compliance. And where we can, we will trend of the level of activity. But where we can, then we'll help support that, document and do it on the appropriate way on the exemption.
